stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the session sculpting the game-ending “retro section,” a gauntlet that stitches together every Mario 64 course.  He constantly monitors RAM usage, tweaks geometry, and debates aesthetic rules (fix UVs, minimal vertex colors).  Side conversations cover emulator choices, a commissioned “Drug Mario” hack, and Nintendo DMCA risks.

development_findings.summary: The final level will combine all Mario 64 stages into one vertical challenge, inspired by Only Up 64 and Champion’s Road.
development_findings.quote: The retro section is not just Lethal Lava Land; it’s going to be every Mario 64 level at the same time.

development_findings.summary: Overworld (all of Yoshi’s Island) still needs to be built; it will be split into multiple areas because one map cannot fit in memory.
Art direction: keep the "vanilla shitty aesthetic" but fix broken UV maps; vertex colors only allowed to emulate baked lighting.
development_findings.quote: I’m trying to make it slightly better than vanilla… no vertex colors, no—well, maybe only to emulate baked lighting.

development_findings.summary: Memory is tight (≈¼ MB free); large geometry is trimmed, sections are split, and triangles removed to stay within the engine’s white-box limits.
development_findings.quote: We are running out of memory, so we have to keep this somewhat low detail.

development_findings.summary: Wing Cap will be obtainable atop the pyramid; level must still be completable without extended moves or the cap; skips are allowed but should feel creative, not trivial.
development_findings.quote: I want this game to be beatable without Mario’s extended moveset.

development_findings.summary: Gameplay tweak: a building is added to block the cannon so the player can safely shoot to the next area.
Technical workflow: using Fast64 exporter, expanded ROMs, compiling with -O2 for performance; prefers Nemu & Project64 1.6; avoids Parallel Launcher.
development_findings.quote: I’m very happy with Nemu… every time I make a hack he patches Parallel Launcher so it can’t run the hack anymore.

development_findings.summary: Planned set-pieces: flamethrowers on the volcano, Yoshi-squid’s home with a bit-pipe, imported submarine model, Peach’s Castle finale with Yoshi giving the star.
Background idea for abandoned Bubble Dome: use a Mode 7-style static panorama to free the camera and reduce walls.
development_findings.quote: Instead of walls around the level, we should have a background like this — it’s going to let the camera be so much more free.

development_findings.summary: ROM banks automatically shift segments behind the frame buffer when overflow detected, confirming custom memory-manager code works.

context_findings.summary: Kaze views a potential Nintendo takedown as a "win-win": either the hack survives or he rebrands it as an original game and sells it on Steam.
context_findings.quote: If Nintendo takes it down, perfect. I can rerun it, sell it on Steam, I’m going to be rich.

context_findings.summary: Expresses frustration toward Parallel Launcher’s developer, believing they intentionally break compatibility with his hacks.
Personal schedule: parents visiting for 10 days and daughter’s baptism next Saturday; streams will pause during that window.
Acknowledges he forgets ideas quickly while streaming (“yapping”) and relies on chat or notes to remember level designs.
context_findings.quote: When I’m yapping I do not remember anything I say. After two seconds, it’s just out of my brain.

context_findings.summary: Philosophy: enjoys allowing skillful skips but insists on maintaining baseline challenge; dislikes trivialization.

biobak.summary: Credited for building most levels in the separate commissioned ‘Drug Mario’ project, showing level-design responsibilities.
biobak.quote: Biobak made like most of the levels here.

zeina.summary: Appears in chat; Kaze mentions they are hate-watching the anime Seven Deadly Sins together, hinting at casual work-life overlap.

key_stories.title: Retro Section Memory Crunch
key_stories.summary: While constructing the all-in-one Mario 64 gauntlet, Kaze repeatedly hits memory ceilings.  He monitors segment sizes, trims geometry, splits the volcano area, and compiles with -O2 to keep the level stable.
key_stories.challenge: Fit a huge multi-course map into N64 memory limits.
key_stories.process: Removed triangles, split platforms, watched Fast64 RAM readouts, and considered moving data behind the frame buffer.
key_stories.outcome: Level now loads with ~¼ MB free, confirming custom memory manager works.
key_stories.key_quote: We have not much space left, maybe like a quarter of a megabyte.

key_stories.title: Flag Controversy in ‘Drug Mario’
key_stories.summary: A level featuring rainbow pride flags drew complaints.  Kaze decides to replace the flags with Bowser-themed protest art to avoid unintended offense.
key_stories.challenge: Community feedback that the ‘Chess’ level’s pride flags felt mocking.
key_stories.process: Discussed options on stream, settled on swapping to Bowser protest imagery.
key_stories.outcome: Planned censorship patch for that level.
key_stories.key_quote: If we all perceive it to be offensive then that’s bad… everything is going to be replaced with Bowser flags and ‘all koopas are bastards’ stickers.

key_stories.title: Nintendo DMCA Contingency
key_stories.summary: Kaze anticipates Nintendo may issue a takedown.  He frames either outcome as beneficial, planning to re-skin the project into an original IP (‘Return to Dinosaur Island’) if necessary.
key_stories.process: Publicly outlines strategy: strip Nintendo assets, keep engine, launch on Steam.
key_stories.outcome: Team and audience know there is a fallback commercial plan.
key_stories.key_quote: I can just rip out their code and their assets and it’s entirely my own game. Nintendo is not the dictator of the world.

open_questions.context: Kaze says the overworld will model all of Yoshi’s Island and must be split into multiple areas, but no design details are given.
